title: 110_s198
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Nunn-Lugar Cooperative Threat Reduction Act of 2007". Congress finds that the possession of weapons of mass destruction by hostile states or terrorist groups poses the greatest threat to national security. It is a top priority to protect the US and its allies from such attacks. The US policy is to ensure compliance with nuclear non-proliferation and chemical weapons treaties. The United States has been well-served by various international treaties and agreements related to the prohibition and control of weapons of mass destruction, including the Chemical Weapons Convention, Biological Weapons Convention, IAEA safeguards system, and control lists of various export control regimes. The Nunn-Lugar Cooperative Threat Reduction program, established by various acts, has achieved significant milestones in nuclear disarmament, including deactivating warheads, destroying missiles, silos, launchers, bombers, and air-to-surface missiles. On February 11, 2004, President George W. Bush called for the expansion of the Nunn-Lugar Cooperative Threat Reduction program to prevent weapons and dangerous materials from falling into the wrong hands. The program helps former Soviet states find employment for weapons scientists and dismantles, destroys, and secures weapons and materials. The Nunn-Lugar Cooperative Threat Reduction program helps former Soviet states find employment for former weapons scientists and dismantles, destroys, and secures weapons and materials from the Soviet WMD arsenal. More work is needed in this area. The Nunn-Lugar Cooperative Threat Reduction program helps former Soviet states with employment for former weapons scientists and securing weapons and materials from the Soviet WMD arsenal. Congress acknowledges the need for further work in this area. The sense of Congress is to utilize all US capabilities to prevent catastrophic terrorism using weapons of mass destruction. This includes pursuing a strategy involving multilateral agreements, missile defense, arms control, and holding nations accountable for violations of nonproliferation treaties. The President must have the authority to use Nunn-Lugar Cooperative Threat Reduction funds to uphold treaties, norms, and standards of conduct, consistent with US law and policy, to reduce the threat of weapons of mass destruction and ensure international peace and security. SEC. 4. REPEAL OF RESTRICTIONS.

    Repeals sections of the Soviet Nuclear Threat Reduction Act of 1991, Cooperative Threat Reduction Act of 1993, and Russian Chemical Weapons Destruction Facilities.

SEC. 5. INAPPLICABILITY OF OTHER RESTRICTIONS.

    Exempts Cooperative Threat Reduction programs from certain restrictions.

SEC. 6. COOPERATIVE THREAT REDUCTION PROGRAMS DEFINED.

    Defines "Cooperative Threat Reduction programs" as specified activities in the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1997.
